awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Power Single-Layer Integration with Component Embedding for Wearable and Internet of Things (IoT) Electronics
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of next-generation power delivery products for the wearable, Internet of Things (IoT), and portable electronics markets.  The proposed manufacturing path may generate opportunities at all levels of the electronics supply chain as the technology is agnostic to the power delivery mode, extensibility to other system components, heterogeneous component integration, and compatibility with emerging chiplet packaging.  Both supply chain (analog chip, passive component, and multiferroic component manufacturers) and end-users may benefit from the proposed technology by creating optimal building blocks with agile designs. The proposed technology may provide low-cost components with the required power densities, size, thickness and system interfaces that may be purchased by various end-users in healthcare, safety, and security.  

This I-Corps project is based on the development of power delivery subsystems with embedded power telemetry units, rectification, and storage in a single thin flex package. Such packages are proposed to be manufactured using low-cost, flex-embedding technologies. The proposed technology may transform biomedical electronic systems from their current 2D assembled architectures with pre-packaged devices to thin embedded modules. The underlying technology is based on a power telemetry approach with multiferroics to provide much higher power densities through external magnetic fields and embedded packaging of multiferroic power telemetry with capacitive storage and thin diodes.  The power modules may be customized to different functions based on the required performance, physiological, and design constraints. Since future components are expected to be thinned and diced to chiplets of less than 100 micron thickness, this approach transforms wafers to systems with the least disruption to the supply chain where device manufacturers can directly adapt their devices to subsystems.  This low-cost manufacturing path may enable high-volume production of power modules, bringing the best combination of multiferroic telemetry with rectification and storage. In addition, the modularity will allow easy extensibility to incorporate building-block component technologies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Wireless power transmission is a key building block for future sensor nodes. Current approaches are based on inductive links or RF telemetry, both of which face limitations in achieving higher power densities and smaller form-factors for emerging IoT sensor nodes and health-monitoring devices. Multiferroic telemetry can address this challenge and provide a new approach for remote powering. FIU has developed such multiferroic power telemetry technologies that can scale-down power telemetry components, operate them at low frequencies and therefore, at higher power densities and can deliver power to sensor nodes that are not easily accessible with traditional approaches. This i-Corps program seeks to commercialize this innovative technology through two key tasks: 1)Customer discovery through the i-Corps workshop, 2)Technology validation by developing proof-of-concept technology prototypes.

 

In the first task, the team participated in an extensive networking task with various industry members. Through this interview process, the team discovered the options for minimum viable product and its market projections, key stake-holders in the customer ecosystem, cost of ownership, R&D qualification gates, cost for production and scale-up.  Students also learned the process of converting fundamental research to strategic research so they can solve key manufacturing problems of the future. Through product survey with industry, the team identified the power delivery market needs for future wearable, textile-embedded, or object-embedded electronic sensing and communication systems of the future. Further, the need for low-cost manufacturing path to enable high-volume production of power modules with wireless power or harvesting schemes that are package-integrated with rectification and storage components is also identified. Modularity will also allow for ease in incorporating next-generation building-block components.

 

In the second task, the team has demonstrated advanced technology integration proof-of-concept prototypes with wireless power telemetry.  Our strategy is to achieve this goal is through piezo-magnetostrictive coupling of external magnetic fields in bulk acoustic resonance modes to achieve high magnetoelectric coefficients.  We integrated such piezo-magnetostrictive architectures with rectifier and storage capacitors for next-generation high-efficiency remotely-powered communication and sensing nodes. Various multi-layered architectures were investigated for output power performance. The multiferroic flexible stacks subsequently integrated with diode rectifier topologies and storage capacitors to generate the desired output.    Results demonstrate new power telemetry opportunities with advanced material stacks with flex package integration. Under resonant conditions, such transducers achieved the target power densities to drive sensing-signal and processing by leveraging wireless communication devices with minimal footprint.

 

With this i-Corps funding, the team is now prepared for the next phase of technology commercialization path. The team is already partnering with a wearable medical device company to utilize this building block in health-monitoring products. As a next step, the team has received certain direct support from the industry partners but will also submit for larger federal grants through NSF PFI or SBIR/STTR. This will help study the product-level process integration, meeting the system performance metrics with long-term stability and reliability, cost structure for the final product implementation and other critical aspects for the stake-holders. The team will also spin-off this multiferroic work in new directions pertaining to the application of this system for communication devices that focus on low power and reconfigurability.

 


Last Modified: 02/12/2023
Modified by: Markondeya Raj Pulugurtha

Images (1 of )
  • Multiferroic laminates were developed for power telemetry and show-and-tell prototypes for potential industry investors and partners.
    IEEE

    Markondeya Raj Pulugurtha
    Fabricated prototypes of multiferroic laminates for power telemetry
  • The fabricated prototypes were characterized for their output power under different load conditions. This set-up will aid in further developing this technology for custom applications.
    IEEE
    Copyrighted
    Markondeya Raj Pulugurtha
    Functional validation of multiferroic power telemetry
